author: Kyle Caldwell
title: The chart that shows investors who try to cut their losses lose in the end
text:
The chart that shows investors who try to cut their losses lose in the end Selling shares when stock markets fall is a bad decision Comments 
As global stock markets continue to whipsaw the temptation for investors is to take their money off the table until calm resumes. 
To do so, however, would risk missing out on some of the most valuable days of stock market gains and lock in lower returns for good. That's according to JP Morgan Asset Managemenet - and they've produced a chart they say proves it. 
It shows what would happen to an investor's return if they missed the very best days of stock market gains over a 10 year period. Missing the best 10 days would almost halve returns, the company said. 
It goes on to explain that the best days of gains very often occur immediately after sharp falls - so anyone who panics will miss out. 
Someone who invested £10,000 in the FTSE 100 20 years ago and reinvested dividends, but missed the best 10 days in the market, would have achieved an annualised return of 3.8pc and ended up with £21,347. 
But those who adopted a buy and hold approach, holding their nerve during aggressive market sell-offs in 2000 during the tech crash and the financial crisis in 2008, would have fared better; making 7.3pc and seeing their investments grow to £41,236. 
David Stubbs, an investment strategist at JP Morgan Asset Management, said: “Selling on days when stock markets plunge can be a recipe for locking in losses. Rather than making usually futile attempts to time the market, focus instead on taking the emotions out of decision making and staying invested for the long term.” 
The FTSE 100 lurched back into the red yesterday, with concerns over slowing economic growth in China once again taking centre stage . 
The index was down 3pc at one stage, trading just above the 6000 points mark, with weak manufacturing data from China the trigger. Since its 7,104 peak on April 27 the index has fallen 14pc. 
But rather than selling in the hope of cutting losses, the answer for most investors is to do nothing and steer clear of trying to predict the peaks and troughs of the stock market.
